In Julia, Write a function `timezone_bumper(dt,bump)` that increases any provided timestamp by `bump::Int` hours (defaults to +3 hours). Make sure it works only for DateTime types and throws an error for Date types.

Sure! Here is your requested function:

```julia
using Dates

function timezone_bumper(dt::DateTime; bump=3)
    if typeof(dt) == Date
        error("Date type is not allowed in this function, use DateTime instead")
    else
       return dt + Hour(bump)
    end
end
```
This function will work for any DateTime type input. If a date (instead of datetime) is passed as an argument, it will raise an error saying "Date type is not allowed in this function, use DateTime instead". 

Please note that the bump parameter defaults to 3 if no value is provided. So, calling `timezone_bumper(dt)` with a DateTime object would increase its timezone by 3 hours and calling `timezone_bumper(dt; bump=5)` with a DateTime object would increase its timezone by 5 hours.
